newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Senate Finance Committee approves tax cut bill.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Senate Finance Committee approves tax cut bill.

text.p: The Senate Finance Committee Thursday approved a bill to cut taxes by a net $85 billion over five years, a week after the House tax-writing committee passed similar legislation.

The two tax bills were expected to go before the full House and Senate, respectively, for a vote next week. Differences between the two proposals must be worked out before a bill can be presented to the president.
The tax bill would implement the tax portion of the balanced budget agreement reached by congressional leaders and the White House last month.
Earlier, Senate Finance Committee Chairman William Roth, a Delaware Republican, said agreement had been reached to make some changes to the initial plan.
Among the changes would be revisions to a proposal that would raise revenues from airline ticket taxes, as well as a new measure to increase the federal tax on cigarettes.
Roth said the cigarette tax proposal would raise the tax by about 20 cents per pack. The current federal tax on cigarettes is 24 cents per pack.
